segments.text: It was a late night community meeting last night, so I'm dragging just a little bit.
My name is Joel Derichen, and I am Assistant Vice President for Community Operations with the Woodlands Corporation.
My personal background started off in the public sector in what used to be called urban renewal and is now called community development.
And I worked for the Minneapolis Housing Authority, Housing Redevelopment Authority, in Minneapolis as a planner.

Then went on to the New York State Urban Development Corporation as a project manager, and then into a nonprofit corporation called Detroit Renaissance, whose ambition was to redevelop downtown Detroit
the Renaissance Center, which is a large, major urban mixed-use project.
It was one of the things that we stimulated to be done when we were there.
And then I followed my interests into the Newtown movement of the late 60s and early 70s by joining a company called the Newfields Development Corporation.
That was in 1974, which was, and Newfields was a 4,000-acre new community, HUD new community, just outside of Dayton, Ohio, in a little town called Trotwood, Ohio.
Trotwood.
Trotwood.
T-R-O-T-W-O-W-D.
I had been following new towns virtually my entire career when I was with Minneapolis Housing Redevelopment Authority, which was from
Oh, let's see.
That was about 1960.
I got out of graduate school.
Where were you?
I was in graduate school at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis.
Were you in architecture or urban?
Public administration.
So it was an MPA you got in?
I got an MPA.
And I took a lot of courses in the School of Architecture and Planning because I had a real interest in it.
And while I was at the University of Minnesota, I did an internship as part of the public administration program there.
I did an internship with Minneapolis Housing Authority.
Having grown up in New York and seeing the public housing projects that were developed there, I was always amazed at how
rational man could develop those things.

And I was curious enough that when offered an internship, I asked them to place me with the housing authority so I could see what kind of idiotic policies might lead to that kind of inhumane kind of habitat development.
It turned out the Minneapolis Housing Authority has done some of the more outstanding public housing development in the country.
And I was pleased to have been able to
And then when I graduated, go on to work there and actually develop some of what has been recognized as some of the more outstanding senior citizen housing in the country.
So I never did find out why New York City developed the kind of housing that it did.
I think it was more economics and pressure for scale than anything else.
But at that time, that was the late 60s, two new towns were getting started.
One of them was Jonathan, southwest of Minneapolis in a small town called Chaska, Minnesota.
And then the first new town in town under the HUD program called Cedar Riverside, which is on the west bank of the Mississippi River, just adjoining the University of Minnesota.
While I was living and working there, going to school there, I was able to see what was going on.
Was there any involvement by the faculty in that kind of development that you noticed?
Well, the principals were actually professors at the university.
They started it.
And so, yeah, there was a lot of involvement.
And then the New York State Urban Development Corporation, which I went to after,
of the Minneapolis Housing Redevelopment Authority, was the developer of four, either three or four new towns.
Actually, three.
I think there was one in Rochester, two in Rochester.
No, I take that back.
One in Rochester, one in Buffalo, New York, and then a new town in town in the middle of the East River called Roosevelt Island.
which the first two of them never got off the ground to speak of, but Roosevelt Island or Roosevelt Island did.
And it is a major in-town development and very successful today.
So I saw those, although I was not directly involved in working there.
I saw what was going on.
So when I had a chance to become involved with a new town,
Newfields in Ohio, I jumped at the opportunity and was involved with the planning and initial stages of development.
But moreover, I was brought in to a large extent because of my background in the public sector.
And Newfields was in the negotiations with HUD regarding the project agreement and the financing.
So for about a year and a half, I spent a lot of time in Washington with HUD negotiating the project agreement.
In behalf of Newfields.
In behalf of Newfields.
And we were successful.
We arranged a $14 million commitment for Newfields.
And unfortunately for the project and most of the projects and
in the Hutt program, they came on stream just as the economy was nosediving into a very deep recession that lasted from 1973 to 1975.
And Newfields So you were in Washington about 72, 72?
Well, I was in Ohio, but I was traveling to Washington, going back and forth quite a bit.
And Newfields opened and closed.
opened in, I think it was the fall of 74, the beginning of 75, and shut down in the fall of 75.
It was just too severe a recession for it to withstand.
And Newfield, the developer at Newfield, did not have the financial wherewithal to sustain that project.
And as we get on and talk about the Woodlands, we'll see that's one of the
significant differences between the Woodlands and the other projects in the HUD program, namely stronger financial backing than any of the other projects have.
Yeah, that's what they would want to be sure to work on a little bit, is that since you've had such a very broad view of the world, is to prepare that world for this.
Yeah.
So I, continuing with my personal escapades,
I left Newfield in 75, and I did consulting among a number of the new communities in the HUD program.
They were all having difficulties because of the time and the recession.
So I consulted for quite a while with Park Forest South, which is a HUD Newtowns in that community south of Chicago.
And then HUD asked me to come to Washington and consult on virtually a full-time basis to help them with what became workout attempts on about five new communities.
Shenandoah, south of Atlanta, and several others, which I did.
And I spent about a year in Washington doing that.
And it was when I was in Washington that they asked me to do some work on the Woodlands.
The Woodlands had applied for a fairly significant grant to develop the Trade Center.
And so I found myself representing HUD in those negotiations.
Met Rob Lapp, who was vice president for governmental affairs, who was representing the Woodlands Corporation.
And HUD wound up giving the Woodlands a $650,000 grant for the Trade Center.
And when that was all over and my work was winding down at HUD, there was an opening here in Rob Lapp's department.
And he invited me to come down and visit the Woodlands.
And I did.
And I wound up working for him.
That's when you were on trade?
Yeah.
I came in.
My official start date was March 1st of 1977 as Director of Governmental Affairs.
And in that position, I was responsible for a lot of grant work, HUD liaison work.
local governmental relations, working with the county, state agencies, and regional council of governments.
By grant work, you mean you wrote proposals?
Yeah, I wrote grant applications.
I think personally, over the years, I've brought in about $16 or $17 million worth of grant proceeds to this corporation.
Overall, I think
the company has gotten something in excess of $30 million.
And so I wrote all the proposals to HUD for community development block grants.
I have gotten grants from the state for parks and participated in writing grant applications to the Department of Energy for various demonstration grants.
So was that one of the reasons why LAP was interested in you, or do you know?
Yeah, I guess.
But you never actually discussed it in that sense.
Well, my public background was something they were looking for here, because the Woodlands, being such a large project, has to deal with public agencies all the time.
But at that time,
We were in a virtual partnership with HUD.
And the corporation, I think, wanted to have somebody who knew how to deal with it.
When I was at the Minneapolis Housing Authority, I was dealing with HUD all the time.
Actually, I was dealing with predecessor agencies.
That was even before HUD was created.
But in the areas of housing, public housing, low and moderate income housing, they needed that here.
We, as part of the program, were required
to develop low- and moderate-income housing.
We're supposed to develop housing that would represent a cross-section of the Houston demography.
And one of the criticisms HUD had of the Woodlands is it wasn't building enough affordable housing.
It wasn't building any low- and moderate-income housing.
I came out of the public sector, a housing background,
with the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
I was building housing across New York State, public-type housing.
And when I came here, that's another thing that I did.
We have now... Well, let me put it this way.
When HUD was still funding those programs, one out of every five units that was built in the woodlands was a subsidized unit.
rent subsidized or mortgage subsidized.
And those were my responsibilities.
So we've developed either directly as the developer or through other companies that specialized in that, I think, well, over 1,000, probably closer to 1,200 subsidized units in the woodlands.
And I was responsible for it.
for doing that.
So in some cases, I was the project manager actually developing those units for the company.
Or I went out and sought out developers who would come in and do it because of specialties that they had.
And also, I brought that kind of expertise into a subsidiary or an affiliate corporation that we have called Mitchell Mortgage Company, where I set up a commercial
division specializing in the use of government financing, tax-exempt bond financing, industrial revenue bonds, and government housing programs.
Are you on, let's say, the board of Mitch Morgans now, or are you directly involved?
No, I'm not.
Let me interrupt you.
One of the questions you raised, you said HUD's concern was that there was insufficient or that there was no
At that time, no.
None?
None.
Now, I've sensed in discussions with some others that Mr. Mitchell always planned, however, to have a community of broad economic base.

Was that because of the economic situation that that had been, I don't want to say neglected, that has all kinds of values associated with it, but that the developers were pushing another segment of the economy rather than...
Or was it because there was no funding from HUD?
Well, I think it's twofold.
HUD was recalcitrant in funding the programs that are promised.
And it wasn't until probably 76, or I think 76 was probably about the year,
when they actually came through on their promises to make grants and other assistance available to the Newtowns to carry out the social objectives of the Newtown program.
And that only came about because there were several developers among the 13 projects that were in the program that finally went to Congress and said, we've entered this program
taking on certain obligations that developers rarely, if ever, take on, and they're of a social nature.
Economic integration, racial integration, the building in the job base as well as housing, those are social objectives, the environment.
developing in a way that's much more costly because you're trying to protect the environment.
And HUD had promised the developers financial assistance to help carry these out because you cannot absorb those costs in the regular profit picture of a private development.
It just can't be done.
And HUD, as I said, reneged on that until several of the developers who were...
There was an association of Newtown developers that would get together periodically, and several of them were very good in understanding the Washington scene and how to get things done politically.
And they went to Congress and got...
If we're up to HUD,
half of the stuff that we're doing here in the Woodlands today never would have been done.
So in summary, this was actually HUD's failure then, is what you're perceiving.
I think it was.
Now HUD, on the other hand, had a philosophical difference also with the way the Woodlands got started.
HUD would have liked to have seen this project start out with only low and moderate income housing.
While HUD agreed contractually that there would be the entire spectrum of housing price in the Woodlands, the staff at HUD never really agreed with that.
And they considered it an anathema when they would come down here and see a golf course.
And they said, why is the federal government doing that?
Well, the Woodlands Corporation, being a developer, understood
that if you started out just with the low end of housing, you'd never get the cross section.
You would stigmatize the Woodlands as being another HUD project.
And they wouldn't differentiate it between a new town and a low income community that HUD has sponsored somewhere else.
So there was a strategy of building upper end housing as well as middle end
and as well as some affordable housing.
Rylan Home was building in here from day one.
They were building housing that started in the low 20s.
So we were not devoid of the lower end of the housing.
But HUD was chapped at the fact that we were building, in those days, what were considered to be expensive homes.
Well, the fact is the Woodlands established its reputation in the marketplace
as being a good quality community.
And because of that, we were able to sell $200,000, $300,000, $400,000 houses, as well as $20,000, $30,000, and $40,000 homes.
And this is unparalleled in Houston and unparalleled in the country.
That's good.
That's a good delineation.
Now, do you think that character is still holding in the Woodlands?
Absolutely.
With the balance?
Absolutely.
It's getting harder to do because of the absence of grants.
We used to get grants to do the infrastructure in areas where we're going to build the low-end product, what we call production builders, Ryland.
Today it's Ryland and Pulte.
But in those days, Ryland and there were some other builders building in that price range.
And what we would do

is by virtue of the fact that we had grants to build the infrastructure, we would then stipulate to the builder that their price range had to reflect the fact that we could sell the lots to them cheaper.
We did not want them to get a windfall profit because we would, in effect, discount the lots to the builder by virtue of the grants that we received.
We had a lower cost basis.
We passed that savings on to the builder and then stipulated that they had to keep their sales price within certain ranges, which we had agreed with HUD.
Did HUD understand what was happening?
Oh, yeah.
Sure.
This was all.
Yeah.
And that's why they gave us the grants.
So everything we did in that regard had been reviewed with HUD and pre-approved by HUD.
And our department...
And then when he left the company, I took over the department.
It was to a large extent, we were that linkage between the development operations and HUD.
We were responsible for all the financial reporting to HUD and all of the contract administration and approvals that were needed.
It was a very laborious
and tedious partnership working with the federal government.
One, I don't recommend to any developer because HUD is trying to protect what it perceives to be the financial or the public interest properly.
So I don't fall for that.
But the way they go about their business is very slow and painstaking.
And a developer has to be responsive to market conditions, which change quickly.
I mean, we can see today that an incident in the Middle East can affect the United States economy very directly, and real estate is affected accordingly.
So a developer has to be able to change gears quickly.
HUD is unable.
The federal government is unable to change gears quickly.
And that was, to a large extent, a very frustrating relationship.
And each party was probably right from their own perspective, but it was a difficult partnership to carry out.
Essentially, the HUD association was seized roughly around 82, 84?
83 was when the final termination agreement was signed.
We worked on that for about two years.
They told us a couple of years before that that they wanted to get out of the business.
We were the only project at that time that was continuing, that was honoring the schedule of repayment of the ventures, that was reporting to HUD.
As I said, before I came to the Woodlands Corporation, I had gone to HUD as a consultant on our workout situation.
Well, mostly what we did was to figure out how HUD could minimize its losses because there weren't very many viable projects.
Financially, there were none except the Woodlands, although a couple of the projects did get sold off and are continuing in some semblance of
the Newtown concept even today.
There are three others besides the Woodlands.
And those are, like, Roosevelt Island?
Well, Roosevelt Island was under a slightly different program.
They got grants, but they never had a debenture guarantee the way the other 13 projects did.
Maumelle in North Little Rock, Arkansas.
is continuing, I'm told, substantially in accordance with the master plan.
The St. Charles in Charles County, Maryland, which is south of Washington also, and Harbison in Columbia, South Carolina also.
Now, they were all financial failures.
And several of them have gone through several owners since had foreclosed and sold it off.
the developers have, to a large extent, stuck to the idea of a master-planned community.
To what do you attribute the success of the Woodlands?
And when you arrived here in 1977, 1980, during that period, how did you compare, in your sense, what was going on here as to what you had seen elsewhere with the new town, new city developments?
Well, let me compare what I saw here with others.
The mix of developers in the New Communities Program was as varied as one could imagine.
You had a number of developers, like George Mitchell,

like Don Huber, who was the president of Newfield's Development Corporation, where I worked, and several others who had visions, who had studied new towns in Europe, and who really believed what they wanted to do, albeit within the context of a for-profit private development,
was to establish prototypes for better land use planning and land development.
Bear in mind that we were coming out of the 60s, which were turbulent times for the American city.
The cities were not working for the populace.
We had also had about 20 years of suburban development, which had virtually
destroyed the natural landscape, had not provided the services that an urbanizing population required, had become bastions of the white middle class, and they were not integrated.
And there were a number of the developers who wanted to show that you could create cities that would not be
full of the problems, replete with the problems of the older cities.
So you had George Mitchell, Huber, and several others.
Lester Gross and Harbison.
OK, so you had your for-profit, the profit-motivated.
Then you had your non-profits.
You had Harbison, sponsored by the Presbyterian Church.
Lester Gross was their president of that corporation.
You had Seoul City.
It was in South Carolina, I believe, or North Carolina.
Floyd McKissick, one of the civil rights leaders, wanted to build a community where it would be integrated, but nevertheless blacks would have a home where they were not second-class citizens.
And it had very much a civil rights bent to it.

You had the New York State Urban Development Corporation, a public, well, it was a public purpose corporation, it was a quasi-public corporation, building three new towns with motives that, again, were
altruistic as were ours, trying to demonstrate that America can do better, can create an urban environment that serves the people and serves them well.
And then, frankly, I saw some developers who saw the HUD guarantee as a way of raising capital to do
their projects without as much of a vision of urbanism as George Mitchell has and had then and a number of the others.
So it ranged over the landscape.
I would say most of the developers, though, were forward-thinking people who wanted to create a better environment and so forth.
In fact, the new housing legislation was sponsored by a congressman from Ohio by the name of Thomas Ashley.
And he really, in the course of his career in Congress, was responsible for a good measure of the urban legislation, the community development legislation, the housing legislation.
And gentlemen like Don Huben from Newfields and George Mitchell and others
worked very closely with him.
The new community legislation is more a product of the private sector than it was a product of the public sector.
HUD came along once the initiative was in motion.
But I give credit to forward-thinking developers like Mr. Mitchell to get the law in motion.
And they, to a large extent, shaped
Now, when you arrived here, what was your impression of what was going on?
Did it jar you?
Did it seem to fit your sensibilities, maybe?
Well, just a little personal side note, when Lapp invited me to come down and visit
and talk about coming to work here.
I was born and raised in Brooklyn, New York, and lived in the North my entire life.
And while I was interested in seeing the Woodlands firsthand, I wasn't that interested in moving to Texas.
And he did a very clever thing.
He said, bring your wife down with you.
Because he knew that the Woodlands was an attractive community, and it was.
After one weekend here, I was sold on the Woodlands as a place to raise a family, and sold on the Woodlands as a place to establish a career.
Which is still the prime motive of the Woodlands.
Sure.
Oh, yes.
I bought the dream hook, line, and sinker.
We had a little girl four and a half years old, and we had another one.
My wife was pregnant.
She was to give birth within three or four months.
And the environment here was just so conducive to raising a family that I did accept the position.
What I didn't know was how much in its infancy, or what I didn't realize, the Woodlands really was.
It had opened in the fall of 1974, but had some slow going because of the recession, which we spoke about earlier.
It was 1974 until about late 1976, so for about a two-year period it was slow going.
It was just starting to crank up.
I guess I didn't fully appreciate the risk that I was taking, making the move, because the woodlands had not really fully established itself or gotten its foothold.
But fortunately, the economy turned around.
Houston began its ascent in 1977.
If you look at the graph, 77 was the year it really took off.
And it turned out not to be that much of a risk.
We still hold the values, the objectives that are embodied
in the HUD program, which are manifested in the project agreement.
There's a section there called the development plan.
It's Exhibit G to the project agreement.
I can get you a copy if you'd like.
And we still hold to those ideals.
My department still pursues low and moderate income housing.
We still may have a very active affirmative action program to attract minorities to the woodlands.
We develop the project to be environmentally sensitive.
Our master plan calls for the introduction of all of the services that a community requires, be they public or private.
We've worked closely with the social service agencies of Montgomery County to make sure that our population is well served.
And those are the things that I do.
I'm kind of the solver.
But those all were pre-existing to the Woodlands' involvement in HUD, were they not?
The goals?
Yeah.
Oh, yeah, Mr. Mitchell.
I mean, that was part of his dream from the outset.
Certainly.
Okay.
Yeah.
Yeah, I mean, HUD, that's a good point.
I mean, we'd be doing these things whether HUD was involved or not.
The only point I was making is that we became contractually bound to do them when HUD was involved.
We are no longer contractually bound, and we continue to do it.
Yeah, there's a continuity there.
Yeah, sure.
And I think that's what makes the Woodlands as successful as it is.
at least last quarter anyway, where number one in housing starts in the Houston area, people are attracted to it.
And they come to the Woodlands, and once they're here a while, they develop almost a religious fervor for the Woodlands.
Dare we not...
put a sign in that's tasteful or take down one tree too many, we're quick to hear about it.
And that's good.
It's good that the people adopt the ideals the way we have and keep our toes to the fire.
Let me ask you another question about that.
And this may seem somewhat out of left field.
One of the things that's really evident, as we've talked to individuals, is that

like yourself many of the people involved in the woodlands corporation share have the same vision they share that vision and they had it off times before they came and working at the woodlands has reinforced it and strengthened it men officially those who who move here and make their homes here also share that vision is that a universal vision do you think

among residents no it's obviously among residents it is why else would they be here but i meant i meant among you know humankind we've heard that from one individual and i wondered if you shared that notion i think that uh as opposed to being you know to operating upon a certain segment that maybe loves trees or you know see there's people living out in arizona obviously they don't know trees see i'm trying to say well
The aesthetic of the woodlands is attractive to some people and is not to others.
I've heard people say, I'd get claustrophobic living with all these trees here.
You can't see more than 20 feet in front of you.
There are people who like the open views.
I think, given a choice,
people will choose a better planned residential setting in which to live.
But choice has a multitude of factors.
Distance to and from work.
The Woodlands is reasonably far out from a lot of employment centers.
Mobility is improving and we're finding that we're attracting people who otherwise
maybe five years ago before the Hardy toll road was opened, before we had the bus service, wouldn't have moved here.

But proximity to work, cost, notwithstanding the fact that we have housing of all price ranges, there still are some built-in costs to live here because the service package, for example, doesn't come free.
So there's a community association assessment
is at Lauren Basin.
At the upper end, it becomes more expensive than in your typical subdivision.

We have a building code here, which means that builders have to build to a higher level of standard than they would otherwise be required if they went outside of Woodlands at 1960 or something like that.
So people are getting better built homes
But per square foot, they cost a little bit more.
So cost is a factor.
People like to be near their family and friends.
And if you grew up in southwest Houston, you're probably not going to move to the woodlands.
So there are a lot of factors which enter in people's decisions as to whether to move or not.
I would say it's probably a universal ideal that all things being equal,
being close to work, being close to family, being close to churches.
If you grew up in a certain church and your roots are there, you may choose to live around there.
And I think that's one reason why we do so much better in selling to people who are moving into Houston from outside.
Two-thirds of the people who move into the limits year in and year out are moving from outside the Houston area.
That's one of the things I wondered about.
One-third of the people come from Houston, one-third come from elsewhere in Texas, and one-third come from out of state or out of country.
And that's been consistent since we opened the windows.
People are rooted and aren't too likely to move very far.
Believe it or not, you know, from what people tell me, moving from southwest Houston to north Houston is considered to be a major move.
I've moved around a lot in my life, so it doesn't seem to be that much.
But more developers are doing master plan communities around the country, and they're attracting larger
shares in the market.
So I think, again, all things being equal and an inclination to move or having to move, people seek out the better developed, better planned communities.
Would you talk a little while about the, if this is an appropriate time, about the relations between the Woodlands Corporation

In fact, the conceptual design for transferring control and authority to the community association, how all this came to be, and what sort of progress is being made, and what sort of problems are occurring that many were anticipating?
That process of transferring control to the community in the community management business is called transition.
Transition typically takes place... Is this something you learned about in school?
I didn't learn about transition in school.
I suspect they weren't even dealing with it.
They weren't dealing with it.
Community associations as a reasonably widespread phenomenon is only about 18 years old.
17, 18 years old.
They really started coming into play around 1973.
And in 1973, there were only about 500 community associations around the country.
And now there are hundreds of thousands, tens of thousands.
I mean, we've got, we estimate, 4,000 to 5,000 community associations in the Houston area alone.
And there has developed a profession
of community management in a national organization called the Community Associations Institute, which trains people to be community managers.
And I'm personally very active in that, and it's been a good experience.
Transition is the process of turning a community association control from the developer to
to the residents of the community.
It happens in condo associations, townhouse associations, and homeowners associations.
It typically takes place when the development is about 85% completed.
And this was a convention which has been institutionalized by Fannie Mae and Ginnie Mae and HUD and so forth.
So a developer has to do it.
The rationale there is during the actual phases of development, the developer needs control of his project.
He needs to be able to make business decisions about what's going to be developed, when it's going to be developed, how it's going to be developed, design decisions, and so forth.
And a community association is considered to be an important part of development.
It's very important to the marketing of the project.
more so on the larger projects, less so on the smaller projects.
But nevertheless, setting it up so that it's economically viable and all of the covenants and the bylaws and all of that are done properly.
And that's the reason it's left in the developer's hands.
But come 85% of completion, the developer
turns it over to the residents.
The authorities, like Fannie Mae and Judy Mayfield, that the developers' interests have been substantially protected, and it's time to turn it over.

And in those situations, generally what they're doing is turning over the assets of the association, the common property, the open space, common areas, swimming pools, tennis courts, things like that.
They also turn over the books and records of the association and any funds that the association has, bank accounts, which the developers hold.
When the Woodlands was conceived, it was conceived to be a 20-year development.
And in the covenants, there is provision for the gradual
increase of resident representatives on the Woodlands Community Association Board of Directors.
So as a number of occupied households would increase, they would get more representation.
But through the 20-year period, which represented, when you look at the projections, about 85% completion of the Woodlands, the developer would have a majority on the board of the WCA.
A mistake was made in the drafting of the covenants.
And that was they put in a date certain when control of the board would transfer or transition from the developer to the community.
And they put in a 1992 date.
Why 20 years?
Well, when you look back at it, every one of the HUD projects was a 20-year project.
whether it was Soul City in South Carolina, or whether it was the Woodlands in Boomtown, Houston, or whether it was Gananda in suburban Rochester, New York.
And that had to do with the length of the adventures.
It had less to do with the market that each one was operating in.
And as I look back on it, it seems fairly obvious that the 20-year was a force fit
to coincide with what hud had just decided
